text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zambian press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Lecturers testifying before a government commission of enquiry blame political interference for student unrest at the country's two universities.
- The farmers' union calls on government to work with the private sector in securing bilateral trade agreements in the agricultural sector.
- Zambia will soon host the first micro-credit open forum as a preparation for the planned Southern African regional summit to be held in August.
- Lecturers accuse deputy health ministr Nkandu Luo of moonlighting by continuing to lecture at the University of Zambia after resigning from the institution to join the government.

- Post editor Fred M'membe files an affadavit in a Lusaka court claiming that former legal affairs minister Rommy Mushota, who has sued the newspaper, is of unsound mind and should not be allowed to take court actions.
- The U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation pledges $750,000 to the cash-strapped Pan African news organisation to meet operational costs.
